Pessimism and Optimism are both unnatural and not realistic. Both are a set way to see life. Both are like a pair of shades with different color. Instead of picking up either of the shades and putting them over your eyes. I recommend that one should opt to increase the clarity of your vision. Pessimists have an ideal of the world which has not been met and cannot accept that reality does not match their ideals. They feel a deep sense of dread about life due to their own choice of not letting go of their ideal to understand life. Until they let go of their presumptions/ideals due to conditioning of the mind/psychological process and lack of deeper understanding and awareness of themselves, they will suffer. The reason one has ideals is because they want the world to suit their personality/psychological process/conditioned mind. Your thoughts are not yours and you have no power of choice until you realize that. Every idea and thought that you have is picked up from the limited experience of your life. That’s why people turn out so different from each other, because we all have different experiences. Once you are aware that what you think is you(personality) is not actually you, you have the power of choice. Once this happens you can start to find out that you really don’t know anything about life and need to re-evaluate everything. More proof that your personality is not you is that you think about/create what you think is your future only from past experiences. Your mind cannot make anything new up from scratch. It needs material/experience/exposure to a situation or stimulus. Most get this “material” unconsciously which is why they are identified with their ideals when in fact it is not their choice to pick their personality, thoughts, ideals up. Once you are aware of this in the present moment you can then get “materials” consciously by allowing yourself to accept/seek new experiences. Suffering mentally is actually a sign that you are not in line or harmony with truth/reality. Only those who seek truth consciously can experience it. As for optimistic people it is the same story flipped. They have great experiences which lead them to have a different mentality/personality/psychological process. Both are untrustworthy and will lead to misunderstanding. People think they have it all figured out and come to conclusions about life based on their limited experiences. I know I don’t know anything about life but am happy to learn and seek as that is the only way. If you do the right thing the right thing will happen. If you do the wrong thing, the right thing can never happen. By right I mean successful/sufficient action. By wrong I mean unsuccessful/insufficient action. No matter your intention or emotion, If the rule to winning a million dollars is that you have to score a goal in soccer with you left foot and you will win, but you score with the right, you won’t win. Only what works will work and what doesn’t work will not. Please seek. Do not believe and come to any conclusion by thought. When you know you know, when you don’t know you don’t know. Honesty with yourself is key. Right and wrong in a moral context is just another boundary you put because you are afraid of the truth. Instead of using morality as a substitute for clarity please seek truth. Human beings all have the same basic mechanism but see how incredibly different we all are because of experiences.

I know this video is suuuuper old and stuff but here's my two cents:
Determining whether the glass is half empty or half full depends on its starting point. If you take and empty glass and fill it half way with water, then the glass is half full (because you filled it). If the opposite is true and you were presented with a full glass of water but drank it down to half then the glass is half empty (because you emptied it). Now if neither of these situations are true and you are presented with a glass that already has water in it then I usually just say that the glass is "at half" or "at 50% capacity".

when you think of the question as a calculus problem rather than a psychological shit test, the answer becomes clear and objective rather than a subjective Rorschach test. the answer follows from the initial parameters of the glass.

if the glass is empty and you begin to fill it - stopping halfway - it is half full.

if the glass is full and you drink from the glass until half is consumed - it is half empty.

there is no subtlety or ambiguity when you think about it This way.

I'm usually pessimistically optimistic, in other words I don't get my hopes up in situations with a favored outcome, but sometimes I'm optimistically pessimistic, meaning I get my hopes up in situations with no favorable outcome in hopes of getting the least unfavorable outcome.  This way I either don't get disappointed or only get a little disappointed.  Whether I'm optimistic or pessimistic is more dependent on my mental status and the situation at hand than anything else, and I doubt that I'm the only one who thinks like this. While this question is interesting, and does prove certain points. It's, also, a perfect demonstration of man kinds current, and eternally defunct mental state, whereby, even in the 21st century, we still persist in entertaining, and amusing ourselves with such redundant, and wasteful queries. We, literally, find a demented glee in establishing a position, whereupon, we can find endless delight in pointing out how ignorant others are, rather than share, out of love, our discovery, and, potentially, new understanding. Also, sadly, such is the nature of man that upon being asked such a question, he will immediately choose a side, and most often argumentatively, and in a typical hostile manner will defend that side till his untimely, and idiotic death. Enter the realm of ignorance and folly. Whereby, man creates struggle for himself where in reality, none exists. Ultimately fascinating is this fact. The answer is simple, but the questions mere structure leads the ignorant to choose sides. Most people never even consider there is a valid third option. It never, ever occurs to them, because so blind are they by the choice to take sides, and in, animalistic, animosity guard their decision they do not, will not, and outright refuse to see another way. Beyond whatever other real insights anyone else has ever had, I came to the conclusion, myself, having never been told by another, that this third option is that the glass exists, being, simultaneously, both half full, and half empty. When this conclusion hit me, I was immediately, astounded by my sheer, and pathetic lack of observation, especially, in the light of having come across this query probably more than a decade ago. There is something to be said for discovering something for oneself. Choosing sides seems, almost always destructive, because , the people involved, usually end up on opposite sides of the solution, and therefor, cut themselves off from it. This in all cases can be remedied by wisdom. There is a new question, now, I think some people will know, while most will never know, and, certainly, most just do not care. And so, we will, endlessly, repeat ourselves until such a time as we all choose to do otherwise. An end to war, poverty, and even death itself can be found in this new question. Or, rather, an old question asked anew.

1. half FULL (from completely empty to half full)
2. half EMPTY (from completely empty to half empty)

A psychologist walked around a room while teaching stress management to an audience. As she raised a glass of water, everyone expected they'd be asked the "half empty or half full" question. Instead, with a smile on her face, she inquired: "How heavy is this glass of water?"

Answers called out ranged from 8 oz. to 20 oz.

She replied, "The absolute weight doesn't matter. It depends on how long I hold it. If I hold it for a minute, it's not a problem. If I hold it for an hour, I'll have an ache in my arm. If I hold it for a day, my arm will feel numb and paralyzed. In each case, the weight of the glass doesn't change, but the longer I hold it, the heavier it becomes."

She continued, "The stresses and worries in life are like that glass of water. Think about them for a while and nothing happens. Think about them a bit longer and they begin to hurt. And if you think about them all day long, you will feel paralyzed – incapable of doing anything."

Remember to put the glass down.
